meta.description: Context Sensitive Help for the table "tx_devnulladdr_address"

languageKey.label: Administrative Area (address of the partner)
The administrative area that the partner's locality belongs to. In the USA, this could be the two-letter State-Code (like 'NY' for New York).
Birth Date of the person

Important Notice: You must enter the birth date exactly in the following format: YYYYMMDD.
Example: 19390209 is February 2, 1939.
Cookbook: You enter the year first (with 4 digits, like 1939), then without a comma or anything you enter the month (with 2 digits, like 02 for february) and then, again with no comma or anything you add the day of the month (with 2 digits, like 09).
Birth Place of the person
Place (possibly including the country) where the person was born.
Building (address of the partner)
Can be used to further refine the address by exactly naming the name of the building where the partner is located (like 'Egis' or 'Beauty Appartments').
Closure Date of the organisation
This is usually the date where the organisation has ceased to formally exist (e.g. if a firm went bankrupt).
Contact Information of the partner
You can enter an unlimited numer of contact informations for the partner here (like phone numbers or e-mail addresses).
Contact permission status for the partner
Defines if and how a partner may be contacted. This list can be defined by your administrator. Possible values could be 'Unrestricted', 'Do not contact' or 'Call X before contacting'.
Country (address of the partner)
The country where the partner resides.
Courses of the partner
Enter all the courses which this partner has visited. The list of possible courses can be defined by your administrator.
Data source of the partner

Describes where the partner has originated. Can be for instance the name of a third-party application. Can be used together with the field 'External ID' to fully identify a partner from an external application.
tx_devnulladdr_address:external_id
Death Date of the person

Important Notice: You must enter the death date exactly in the following format: YYYYMMDD.
Example: 19390209 is February 2, 1939.
Cookbook: You enter the year first (with 4 digits, like 1939), then without a comma or anything you enter the month (with 2 digits, like 02 for february) and then, again with no comma or anything you add the day of the month (with 2 digits, like 09).
Death Place of the person
Place (possibly including the country) where the person has died.
Department (address of the partner)
Usually used for business addresses, if the partner is a member of or has the address of a certain department.
Invalid Keyword used

You have used a keyword other than PRIVATE, RESTRICTED or PUBLIC in your TSconfig setup. Therefore, the system cannot assign a default value for this field. Please note that the keywords are case-sensitive! You must use capital letters. Please refer to the following example for a proper setup.
EXT:partner/csh/img/field_visibility_default_settings.png
External Identification of the partner
Contains the identification of this partner in an external application, which is usually defined in the field 'Data Source'.
tx_devnulladdr_address:data_source
Frontend User ID of the partner
If this partner is also a frontend user, then the user record can be linked to the partner by entering the frontend user ID in this field.
Field Visibility Settings
In this table, you can see all the settings which concern the visibility of partner and contact-information fields in the frontend.
No Default Values found

The system could not find any default values for the field visibility settings. You can configure the default values in TSconfig in your sys-folder. For details, please refer to the manual (reference section).
EXT:partner/csh/img/field_visibility_default_settings.png
First Name of the partner
Enter only the first name here. There are additional fields for the middle and the last name of the partner.
Floor (address of the partner)
Can be used to further refine the address by exactly naming the floor where the partner is located.
Formation Date of the organisation
If known, you can enter the date of the formation of the organisation here.
Gender of the person
Enter the gender (sex) of the partner. The list of values are defined by ISO 5218.
General Suffix of the partner
If the whole name of the partner should be suffixed, you can enter this suffix here. Examples would be 'retired' or 'deceased'.
Hobbies of the partner
Enter all the hobbies of this partner. The list of possible hobbies can be defined by your administrator.
Image of the partner
You can upload one picture of the partner here. This picture may for instance be used when displaying partner records on your website.
Initials of the partner
Usually formed by the first, middle and last name of a partner, but you can use this according to your own syntax. Example: 'Paul J. Miller' could have the initials 'PJM'.
Join Date of the partner
If you manage the partner data of a club, then this might be the date at which the partner joined your club.
Label of the partner

The label is used in many places in the backend, usually when the partner has to be described with just one field. The value of the label is formed by TYPO3 in the following way:
For Persons
[Last name], [First Name] - [Locality]

For Organisations
[Name of Organisation] - [Locality]
Name for the person/address
Enter only the last name (e.g. family name) here. There are additional fields for the first and the middle name of the partner.
Last Name Prefix of the partner
If the last name of the partner should be prefixed, you can enter this prefix here. For instance 'de la' or 'van den', etc.
Leave Date of the partner
If you manage the partner data of a club, then this might be the date at which the partner left your club.
Letter Title of the partner
Defines a special letter title just for this partner, if applicable. If this field is blank, then letters to this partner will feature the standard letter title (like 'Dear Mr. xyz')
Locality (address of the partner)
The partner's locality. Do not enter the postal code here. There is an additional field just for the postal code.
Maiden Name of the partner
This field can be used to enter the maiden (unmarried) name of the partner. Please note that this name will usually not be used to display or print, but server just for information.
Marital Status of the person
Enter the marital status (e.g. 'married' or 'single') of the person. This list can be defined by your administrator.
Meeting Period of the organisation
Enter the period in which the organisation will meet. If the organisation meets every 2 weeks, you would enter a '2' here and chose 'weeks' as the meeting unit.
tx_devnulladdr_address:meeting_unit, tx_devnulladdr_address:meeting_start_date
Meeting Start Date of the organisation

Enter the date at which the meeting series shall start or has started. The system will calculate the dates of further meetings based on this date.
Example:
If your organisation meets every 2 weeks, always on a monday, you would enter a '2' as meeting period and chose 'weeks' as the meeting unit. Then you would enter a date here that was a monday, like 27-09-2004.
tx_devnulladdr_address:meeting_period, tx_devnulladdr_address:meeting_unit
Meeting Unit of the organisation

Enter the unit in which the organisation will meet. If the organisation meets every 2 weeks, you would chose 'weeks' here and enter a '2' in the field Meeting Period. The list of possible meeting units is defined by the Partner-Extension.
tx_devnulladdr_address:meeting_period, tx_devnulladdr_address:meeting_start_date
Middle Name of the partner
Enter only the middle name here. There are additional fields for the first and the last name of the partner.
Mother Tongue of the person
This is the language that the person grew up with.
Nationality of the partner
Enter the country of the partner's nationality.
Occupations of the partner
Enter all the occupations of this partner. The list of possible occupations can be defined by your administrator.
Legal Form of the organisation
Defines the legal form of the organisation, if applicable. This list can be defined by your administrator.
Organisation Name
Full name of the organisation, for instance the name of the firm or the name of a group of persons.
Organisation Type
Defines the type of organistion, for instance a firm, a club, a group, or anything else which is not a person. This list can be defined by your administrator.
PO Box Administrative Area (address of the partner)
The administrative area that the partner's PO box locality belongs to. In the USA, this could be the two-letter State-Code (like 'NY' for New York).
PO Box Country (address of the partner)
The country of the partner's PO box.
PO Box Locality (address of the partner)
The partner's PO box locality. Do not enter the postal code of the PO box here. There is an additional field just for the PO box postal code.
PO Box without number (address of the partner)
If the partner has a post box (PO box), but the PO box is not numbered, you can check this box.
Post Box Number (address of the partner)
If the partner has a post box (PO), you can enter the number here.
PO Box Postal Code (address of the partner)
The postal code (or ZIP-code) or the partner's PO box locality.
Postal Code (address of the partner)
The postal code (or ZIP code) of the partner's locality.
Preceding Title of the partner
Describes any titles that must be used before the actual title of the partner. Examples: 'His Excellency', 'Honorable', etc.
Preferred Language of the partner
Enter the language in which the partner should be contacted.
List of all relationships for this partner

This list gives you an overview about all the relationships that were entered for this partner. You can also change existing relationships, change related partners or create new relationships.

Primary or Secondary Partner?
A relationship always consists of exactly two partners. One is the primary partner, the other is the secondary partner. The type of a relationship defines what kind of relationships the two partners have.

Let's say, for instance, that one partner is the member of the other, like a member of a club. Well in this case, the relationship type you want to have is 'has member'. You can see already from the formulation of the type that there is a 'direction' to the relationship. Club Y 'has member' Mr. Miller and not the other way round. So Club Y is the primary partner and Mr. Miller is the secondary partner.

Let's take another example. You would like to know who belongs to a certain family. Your administrator has configured the relationship types 'has child' and 'has wife' for this purpose. Again you see from the formulation that each of these types have a 'direction'. So Mr. and Mrs. Miller have a child, David. You would therefore create three new partners: Mr. Miller, Mrs. Miller and David Miller. In order to enter the family relationship, you would open the record of Mr. Miller and create a new relationship as 'primary partner'. Then you would chose the type 'has child' and enter David Miller as secondary partner. Secondly, you would create a new relationship, again with Mr. Miller as the primary partner, chose 'has wife' as type and enter Mrs. Miller as secondary partner. And here you are, you just created your family!
Religion of the partner
Enter the religion of the person. This list can be defined by your administrator.
Room (address of the partner)
Can be used to further refine the address by exactly naming the room (usually a number) where the partner is located.
Status of the partner
Describes the current status of the partner. The list of possible status can be defined by your administrator. Possible values could be 'Active', 'Passive' or 'To be archived'.
Street (address of the partner)
Name of the street (as part of the address).
Street Number (address of the partner)
Street Number of the partner's building (as part of the address).
Title of the partner
Defines the title of the partner, for instance 'Mister', 'Professor', 'Dr.', etc. This list can be defined by your administrator.
